Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-cost, wireless, energy harvesting environmental sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project would be commercial availability of a low-cost, wireless, energy-harvesting environmental sensor for high-granularity sensing, feedback, and control to a number of markets including buildings, industrial, agricultural, and any other application that would benefit from monitoring where power or access is in short supply. The primary target market for this technology is the buildings sector, where the proposed wireless sensor network will be transformational for building monitoring and control. The high temporal and spatial resolution of the data delivered by this system additionally contains, given the proper analysis, actionable information with impacts on system operation, efficiency, and safety. The data analysis development proposed will take a first important step towards the automatic identification and extraction of this high value actionable information.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on the development of a low-cost, wireless, and energy harvesting environmental sensor, and a data aggregation / visualization platform to enable effective communication of data to users and control systems. This project addresses major barriers in the main market, the application of Internet of Things to the buildings sector, where complexity is encountered in the placement and powering of sensors in monitoring locations where access is limited. By reducing the upfront and maintenance costs of wireless sensor networks, the project allows cost-effective building sensor data collection of unprecedented longevity and density. These rich data sets in turn enable myriad benefits, including more effective building management controls and in-depth automated energy evaluations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses major barriers in our main market, the application of Internet of Things (IoT) to the buildings sector, where complexity is encountered in the placement and powering of sensors in monitoring locations where access is limited. While the opportunities for energy efficiency improvements within the buildings sector are significant with dense monitoring, current solutions do not support widespread adoption. Systems that require wired connection for power or data typically incur significant installation costs, and commercially available wireless sensor systems suffer from limited lifetimes, as operating lifetime is governed by battery capacity. As a result, for current solutions, high upfront installation costs and/or required system maintenance costs significantly reduces the cost-effectiveness for dense sensor installations and poses a barrier to technology adoption. By reducing the upfront and maintenance costs of wireless sensor networks, the project allows cost-effective building sensor data collection of unprecedented longevity and density.

This Phase I project proposed to develop low-cost, wireless, energy harvesting environmental sensors.  The project has successfully resulted in a Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 7 sensor prototype which can maintain an energy positive budget in median indoor light conditions, while transmitting at 10 minute intervals. The sensors communicate both temperature and humidity readings wirelessly via ZigBee protocol, and demonstrated the feasibility of net positive energy performance with extremely low packet loss within a building pilot. The accuracy of the temperature and humidity readings of the prototype sensor were shown to be equivalent to current sensor offerings on the market.

This Phase 1 project additionally aimed to develop data infrastructure and analytics to support the storage, aggregation and display of the communicated sensor data. To this end a system of cloud infrastructure to manage sensor data was required, in addition to a platform to view the communicated data in real-time. Through the program a building management web application was developed to display sensor data and resulting insights from wirelessly transmitted building temperature and operational data. The conceptual design of the web application was driven by the customer need to visualize building temperatures, and indicators of potential operational issues in real-time. A scalable API infrastructure was additionally developed to support secure, authenticated data requests via the web application. Users can view their portfolio of buildings, with average temperatures across each building, floor, or single room. This dashboard additionally lays significant groundwork for communicating data and insights derived from the developed sensor product.
